segments.pli: “Dāruṇo, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko kaṭuko pharuso antarāyiko anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
segments.en: “Possessions, honor, and popularity are brutal, bitter, and harsh. They’re an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary.

segments.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
segments.en: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand:
‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of their mother.’

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūtaṃ pariyādiṇṇacittaṃ sampajānamusā bhāsantaṃ.
segments.en: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.

segments.pli: Evaṃ dāruṇo kho, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko kaṭuko pharuso antarāyiko anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
segments.en: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity—bitter and harsh, an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary.
So you should train like this:
‘We will give up arisen possessions, honor, and popularity, and we won’t let them occupy our minds.’

segments.pli: Na ca no uppanno lābhasakkārasiloko cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatī’ti.
